paragraphs.text: %md # Association Rules (Market Basket Analysis) The Association Rules machine learning technique, also known as Market Basket Analysis, can be used when looking for co-occurring items, states that lead to failures, or non-obvious cobinations of events, e.g., as in manufacturing. In his notebook, you will build association rules models using the A Priori algorithm with data from the SH schema (SH.SALES). All computation occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database. Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

msg.data:
Association Rules (Market Basket Analysis)

The Association Rules machine learning technique, also known as Market Basket Analysis, can be used when looking for co-occurring items, states that lead to failures, or non-obvious cobinations of events, e.g., as in manufacturing. In his notebook, you will build association rules models using the A Priori algorithm with data from the SH schema (SH.SALES). All computation occurs inside Oracle Autonomous Database.

Copyright (c) 2022 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: Import libraries and set display options
Get SALES proxy object and display a few rows of data
paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.sync(query = c("SALES_DF" = "SELECT CUST_ID, PROD_ID, QUANTITY_SOLD, AMOUNT_SOLD, CHANNEL_ID, PROMO_ID FROM SH.SALES"))
ore.attach()
z.show(head(SALES_DF))

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Get PRODUCTS proxy object and display a few rows of data
paragraphs.text:
%r

ore.sync(query = c("PRODUCT_DF" = "SELECT PROD_ID, PROD_NAME, PROD_CATEGORY FROM SH.PRODUCTS"))
ore.attach()

z.show(head(PRODUCT_DF))

paragraphs.title: Merge SALES with PRODUCT, creating another proxy object
paragraphs.text:
%r

SALES_TRANS_CUST <- merge(PRODUCT_DF, SALES_DF[(SALES_DF$CUST_ID >= 100001 & SALES_DF$CUST_ID <=104500),])
SALES_TRANS_CUST <- unique(SALES_TRANS_CUST[c("CUST_ID", "PROD_NAME","PROD_CATEGORY")])

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Examples of possible setting overrides for Association Rules (A Priori)

If the user does not override the default settings, then relevant settings are determined by the algorithm

A complete list of settings can be found in the Documentation link:

– Algorithm Settings: [Association Rules - A Priori](https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/machine-learning/oml4py/1/mlpug/association-rules.html)

– Shared Settings: [All algorithms](https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/machine-learning/oml4py/1/mlpug/shared-settings.html)

– Specify a missing value treatment method for the training data. This setting does not affect the scoring data. The default value is `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO`. The option `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_MEAN_MODE` replaces missing values with the mean (numeric attributes) or the mode (categorical attributes) both at build time and apply time where appropriate. The option `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO` performs different strategies for different algorithms. When `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT` is set to `ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_DELETE_ROW`, the rows in the training data that contain missing values are deleted. However, if you want to replicate this missing value treatment in the scoring data, then you must perform the transformation explicitly.

```
'ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT' : 'ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO'
```
– Specify the name of a column that contains the items in a transaction.
When you specify this setting, the algorithm expects the data to be presented in native transactional format, consisting of two columns: (1) Case ID, either categorical or numeric, and (2) Item ID, either categorical or numeric.

```
'ODMS_ITEM_ID_COLUMN_NAME' : '<column name>'    
```
– Specify the Minimum support for association rules.

```
The default value is 0.1.  It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive).
'ASSO_MIN_SUPPORT' : '0.1'
```
– Specify the Minimum confidence for association rules.

```
The default value is 0.1.  It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive).
'ASSO_MIN_CONFIDENCE' : '0.1'
```
– Specify the Maximum rule length for association rules.

```
The default value is 4.  It requires a number between 2 and 20 (inclusive).
'ASSO_MAX_RULE_LENGTH': '4'
```

msg.data:
Examples of possible setting overrides for Association Rules (A Priori)

If the user does not override the default settings, then relevant settings are determined by the algorithm

A complete list of settings can be found in the Documentation link:

– Algorithm Settings: Association Rules - A Priori

– Shared Settings: All algorithms

– Specify a missing value treatment method for the training data. This setting does not affect the scoring data. The default value is ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO. The option ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_MEAN_MODE replaces missing values with the mean (numeric attributes) or the mode (categorical attributes) both at build time and apply time where appropriate. The option ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO performs different strategies for different algorithms. When ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT is set to ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_DELETE_ROW, the rows in the training data that contain missing values are deleted. However, if you want to replicate this missing value treatment in the scoring data, then you must perform the transformation explicitly.

'ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_TREATMENT' : 'ODMS_MISSING_VALUE_AUTO'

– Specify the name of a column that contains the items in a transaction.
When you specify this setting, the algorithm expects the data to be presented in native transactional format, consisting of two columns: (1) Case ID, either categorical or numeric, and (2) Item ID, either categorical or numeric.

'ODMS_ITEM_ID_COLUMN_NAME' : '<column name>'

– Specify the Minimum support for association rules.

The default value is 0.1.  It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive).
'ASSO_MIN_SUPPORT' : '0.1'

– Specify the Minimum confidence for association rules.

The default value is 0.1.  It requires a number between 0 and 1 (inclusive).
'ASSO_MIN_CONFIDENCE' : '0.1'

– Specify the Maximum rule length for association rules.

The default value is 4.  It requires a number between 2 and 20 (inclusive).
'ASSO_MAX_RULE_LENGTH': '4'

paragraphs.title: Define settings and create Association Rules model
paragraphs.text:
%r

AR.MOD <- ore.odmAssocRules(~., SALES_TRANS_CUST, 
                            case.id.column = "CUST_ID", 
                            item.id.column = "PROD_NAME", 
                            min.support = 0.04, 
                            min.confidence = 0.1, 
                            max.rule.length = 2)

msg.data:
Call:
  ore.odmAssocRules(formula = ~., data = SALES_TRANS_CUST, case.id.column = "CUST_ID", 
    item.id.column = "PROD_NAME", min.support = 0.04, min.confidence = 0.1, 
    max.rule.length = 2)

Settings: 
                                               value
asso.max.rule.length                               2
asso.min.confidence                              0.1
asso.min.rev.confidence                            0
asso.min.support                                0.04
asso.min.support.int                               1
odms.details                             odms.enable
odms.item.id.column.name                   PROD_NAME
odms.missing.value.treatment odms.missing.value.auto
odms.sampling                  odms.sampling.disable
prep.auto                                         ON

paragraphs.title: Display pie chart of top 10 most frequent purchased items
paragraphs.text:
%r

itemsets <- AR.MOD$itemsets
purchased_items = itemsets[order(itemsets$NUMBER_OF_ITEMS, itemsets$SUPPORT, decreasing = TRUE),]
z.show(head(purchased_items, 10))

paragraphs.title: Display top Association Rules sorted by confidence and support
paragraphs.text:
%r

rules <- AR.MOD$rules
top_12 = rules[order(rules$CONFIDENCE, rules$SUPPORT, decreasing = TRUE),]
z.show(head(top_12, 12))

paragraphs.title: Plot top 12 Association Rules by confidence

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: What items should we recommend when customer has "Standard Mouse" in basket?
paragraphs.text:
%r

recommended <- rules[which(rules$LHS == "Standard Mouse"), ]
results = recommended[order(recommended$CONFIDENCE, decreasing = TRUE),]
z.show(results)
